title: Physics
description: A progressive exploration of fundamental physical laws, concepts, and theories, from classical mechanics to modern physics.

paragraphs.summary: An introduction to Physics as the natural science that studies matter, its motion and behavior through space and time, and the related entities of energy and force.
The empirical method of acquiring knowledge involving observation, hypothesis formulation, experimentation, and refinement of theories based on evidence.
The systems and standards used for quantifying physical properties, including base units (meter, kilogram, second) and derived units.
Distinguishing scalar quantities (magnitude only, e.g., speed, mass) from vector quantities (magnitude and direction, e.g., velocity, force).
The branch of mechanics concerned with the motion of objects without reference to the forces that cause the motion.
Understanding distance as the total path length traveled and displacement as the change in position (a vector quantity).
Defining speed as the rate of change of distance and velocity as the rate of change of displacement (a vector).
The rate at which the velocity of an object changes over time; a vector quantity.
An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force (Law of Inertia).
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass (F=ma).
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction; forces always occur in pairs.
An interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object. A vector quantity, measured in Newtons.
Distinguishing mass as a measure of an object's inertia (amount of matter) from weight as the force of gravity acting on an object.
A force that resists the relative motion or tendency toward such motion of two surfaces in contact.
The energy transferred to or from an object via the application of force along a displacement (W = Fd cos θ).
The energy an object possesses due to its motion, dependent on its mass and speed (KE = 1/2 mv²).
Energy stored in an object due to its position or configuration (e.g., gravitational potential energy, elastic potential energy).
The fundamental principle that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant over time; energy can transform but not be created or destroyed.
The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred, measured in Watts (Joules per second).
The product of an object's mass and its velocity (p=mv); a vector quantity.
In a closed system, the total momentum remains constant if no external forces act upon it.
The change in momentum of an object; equal to the force applied multiplied by the time duration of the force (Impulse = FΔt = Δp).
The movement of an object along the circumference of a circle or rotation along a circular path.
A force that acts on a body moving in a circular path and is directed towards the center around which the body is moving.

Newton's law stating that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
Three scientific laws describing the motion of planets around the Sun, formulated by Johannes Kepler.
A specific type of periodic motion where the restoring force on the moving object is directly proportional to the object's displacement magnitude and acts towards the object's equilibrium position.
Distinguishing between transverse waves (oscillations perpendicular to propagation, e.g., light) and longitudinal waves (oscillations parallel to propagation, e.g., sound).
Key characteristics of waves: amplitude (maximum displacement), wavelength (spatial period), frequency (oscillations per unit time), and period (time for one oscillation).
Longitudinal waves that propagate as acoustic waves, through a transmission medium such as a gas, liquid or solid.
The change in frequency or wavelength of a wave in relation to an observer who is moving relative to the wave source.
If two thermodynamic systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third, then they are in thermal equilibrium with each other; defines temperature.
Temperature as a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles; heat as the transfer of thermal energy between systems.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed in an isolated system; the change in internal energy of a system is equal to the heat added to the system minus the work done by the system.
The total entropy of an isolated system can only increase over time or remain constant in ideal cases where the system is in a steady state or undergoing a reversible process.
A thermodynamic quantity representing the unavailability of a system's thermal energy for conversion into mechanical work, often interpreted as the degree of disorder or randomness in the system.
The study of stationary electric charges or fields as opposed to electric currents.
The physical property of matter that causes it to experience a force when placed in an electromagnetic field; exists as positive or negative.
Describes the electrostatic force of attraction or repulsion between two point charges.
A region around a charged particle or object within which a force would be exerted on other charged particles or objects.
The amount of work needed to move a unit of positive charge from a reference point to a specific point inside an electric field without producing an acceleration; also known as voltage.
The ability of a system to store an electric charge; the ratio of the change in an electric charge in a system to the corresponding change in its electric potential.
A stream of charged particles, such as electrons or ions, moving through an electrical conductor or space.
Electrical resistance is the opposition to the passage of an electric current through a conductor. Ohm's Law states V=IR (Voltage = Current × Resistance).
Electric circuits in which the current flows in only one direction (Direct Current), typically involving resistors, capacitors, and inductors.
A class of physical phenomena that are mediated by magnetic fields. Electric currents and the magnetic moments of elementary particles give rise to a magnetic field.
The branch of physics concerned with the forces that occur between electrically charged particles, encompassing both electricity and magnetism as manifestations of the same phenomenon.
A set of four fundamental equations that describe how electric and magnetic fields are generated and altered by each other and by charges and currents.
Waves of the electromagnetic field, propagating at the speed of light through a vacuum. Includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays.

Reflection is the change in direction of a wavefront at an interface between two different media so that the wavefront returns into the medium from which it originated. Refraction is the change in direction of a wave passing from one medium to another.
Optical devices that refract (lenses) or reflect (mirrors) light to form images or concentrate light.
The branch of optics that studies interference, diffraction, polarization, and other phenomena for which the ray approximation of geometric optics is not valid.

Albert Einstein's theory (1905) regarding the relationship between space and time for objects moving at constant speeds in a straight line. Key concepts include time dilation, length contraction, and E=mc².
Albert Einstein's geometric theory of gravitation (1915), which describes gravity not as a force but as a curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy.
A fundamental theory in physics that provides a description of the physical properties of nature at the scale of atoms and subatomic particles.
The concept in quantum mechanics that every particle or quantum entity may be partly described in terms not only of particles, but also of waves.

A fundamental principle in quantum mechanics stating that there is an inherent limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties of a particle (e.g., position and momentum) can be simultaneously known.
The structure of an atom, consisting of a positively charged nucleus (protons and neutrons) surrounded by negatively charged electrons arranged in orbitals.
The field of physics that studies atomic nuclei and their constituents and interactions, including radioactivity, fission, and fusion.
The branch of physics that studies the nature of the particles that constitute matter and radiation, and the fundamental forces governing them (Standard Model).
The scientific study of the large scale properties of the universe as a whole, including its origin (Big Bang), evolution, structure, and ultimate fate.

The branch of astronomy concerned with the physical nature of stars and other celestial bodies, and with the application of the laws and theories of physics to the interpretation of astronomical observations.
